answers.name: Answer 2
answers.text:
Recently, I have. I’ve started working out because I want to have a good physique when I am older and because of the Beep test, the Beep test is a test of endurance and stamina in which many students participate in. I’ve started working on my stamina, endurance, strength and overall fitness.
 
I return from school at 4:10 pm, once I get home, I sit with a healthy snack and watch some YouTube and study. At 6 pm. That’s when I start lifting, I don’t have my own dumbbells/weights, so I use my tenant’s (I have permission to). Simple, easy lifting, I don’t know how much the weight is but I am just 13,
Continue Reading
Recently, I have. I’ve started working out because I want to have a good physique when I am older and because of the Beep test, the Beep test is a test of endurance and stamina in which many students participate in. I’ve started working on my stamina, endurance, strength and overall fitness.
 
I return from school at 4:10 pm, once I get home, I sit with a healthy snack and watch some YouTube and study. At 6 pm. That’s when I start lifting, I don’t have my own dumbbells/weights, so I use my tenant’s (I have permission to). Simple, easy lifting, I don’t know how much the weight is but I am just 13, so it’s not so much. I lift for 30 mins - 1 hr. Then I take my dog for a walk, after walking my dog, I put her back inside and go to jog. First several seconds I brisk walk, then I walk a bit faster, after, once I’ve reached the end of the sidewalk, where I must turn right to continue onto the sidewalk, I start to jog, once I’ve crossed another patch of the roads, I start to run, then jog, then brisk walk, then just walk. Sometimes I try and run the whole way, but it usually doesn't work.
 
After that, I head back inside, by the time I’m back, it’s usually late (around 7:40 or 8:15 pm), still, I continue to exercise, Russian twists, jumping jacks, squats, push-ups (modified), stretching, etc…
 
It feels nice to use the energy I have after school instead of sitting around and playing video games until 12 am, that’s what I used to do, but once I realized just how important my health is, I started working out. You can use this schedule too, but if you don’t have dumbbells/weights, I recommend using filled milk cartons or something heavy which you can grasp and lift. I am also thinking about getting a gym membership and a gym nearby, so maybe get one of those, they cost money but it’s worth it.

In shot, almost everyday.
 
I actually am in confusion as I try to make a perfect routine. But for now I workout everyday. My rest is the day when I don’t feel like training and that does not mean I am cheating. The only reason my routine is not perfect is because I need a permanent rest day. Everyday I wake up I feel like working my ass off. Even in those days when my body feels like it can not move. Rest day is the greatest punishment for me.

No, but I weight train.
 
In my life I have always lifted weights,bodying building up until I hit a low point in my life. But after many years of losing sight of myself I went back to it, my body takes to it very well. Being a mesomorph I gain muscle very fast, fast falls off me and muscle memory kicks in and they remember exactly what I once did and fall back into place.

answers.name: Answer 11
answers.text: I’m going to spare you the language joke that’s been made many times, and say that I definitely do go to the gym. While it is cheaper to work out at home or outside, the routines I can do on weight machines at a gym are far more beneficial to me than anything I’ve been able to do on my own. I like the benefits of being able to explore different classes and try new kinds of workouts. My gym also has a pretty great community of people who exercise around the same time, and it’s nice to have people hold me accountable.

answers.name: Answer 12
answers.text:
Hell yeah! More than you think. Anybody who says differently about workouts are dumb and insecure. I’m sorry. As mean as it sounds, it’s the truth.
 
I haven’t got into workouts until I was 23 years old. Workouts, for the most part, are my biggest comfort. My therapy. Without it, I don't know how my life would look.

work out basically depends on ones body structure and goals.
 
If one wants to loose weight than they tend to do more of weight loss exercise and on other hand if one wants to gain muscle than one will tend to do weight training.
 
i workout 6 days week and take one day off for recovery. stating the week with workout of back on Monday, chest on Tuesday, legs on Wednesday (legs and back not together just to give some recovery time for lower back). work out basically depends on ones body structure and goals.
 
If one wants to loose weight than they tend to do more of weight loss exercise and on other hand if one wants to gain muscle than one will tend to do weight training.
 
i workout 6 days week and take one day off for recovery. stating the week with workout of back on Monday, chest on Tuesday, legs on Wednesday (legs and back not together just to give some recovery time for lower back). Biceps and triceps on Thursday Shoulder and traps on Friday and finally cardio on Saturday (some cardio is also important so that muscles don’t gets stiffer)(can skip cardio if not want to participate in competitions). I do abs workout on Wednesday and Saturday. I see that i give all muscle group enough time to recover.
 
I am planning to change this routine after 4 months so my body don’t get used to the routine.

answers.name: Answer 18
answers.text:
As Cameron says, I go to a gym frequently but I don’t recall ever hitting it.
 
I had my knee replaced in September of last year, and the rehab exercises I was shown can best be performed on various resistance machines of the sort you can only really get at a well-equipped gym.
 
When I started back to work, I took advantage of our university’s brand new recreation center with state-of-the-art equipment to continue my rehab efforts, and decided to work the rest of my old bod as well.
 
So I do aerobic stints on the stationary bike (very knee-friendly) controlled leg work on the leg press, leg curl, hip
Continue Reading
As Cameron says, I go to a gym frequently but I don’t recall ever hitting it.
 
I had my knee replaced in September of last year, and the rehab exercises I was shown can best be performed on various resistance machines of the sort you can only really get at a well-equipped gym.
 
When I started back to work, I took advantage of our university’s brand new recreation center with state-of-the-art equipment to continue my rehab efforts, and decided to work the rest of my old bod as well.
 
So I do aerobic stints on the stationary bike (very knee-friendly) controlled leg work on the leg press, leg curl, hip addiction/abduction machine, and the regular suite of upper-body work as well.
 
This has been working very well and at my age (70) I’m making good progress with overall strength and my knee is coming along nicely.
 
(Takes up to a full year for complete healing)
 
Here’s a minor peeve of mine. The use of the term “gym” as a synonym for “lifting weights”. Our gym has the full suite of both resistance equipment and aerobic equipment. Bikes, steppers, elliptical, rowing, treadmill, etc.
 
In addition, there’s indoor basketball courts, swimming, spinning, yoga, Pilates, etc, etc. You can do pretty much any sort of activity you like, and this is the case with many commercial gyms.
